dialogue.text: On Earth, we question with our feet on the ground. Here, we question while suspended, literally groundless. It changes everything.
I feel like I'm nothing. Like I don't exist if I can't define myself.
I am undefined, ungrounded, uncertain. And yet... I have never existed more fully than in this moment of complete not-knowing.
My grandmother says they were like actors who forgot they were playing roles, trapped in costumes they couldn't remove.
I like being groundless! It means I can be upside down and right-side up at the same time. Just like the question!
Don't worry about not knowing who you are. Nobody knows, and that's what makes us all friends.

visual_elements.earth_in_sky: Home planet visible as reminder of journey

psychological_notes: Mars provides unique environment for exploring uncertainty—literal groundlessness mirrors psychological state. Different gravity creates different neural patterns in children. Physical floating enables emotional/psychological floating. Frightened woman represents last generation to struggle with uncertainty.
philosophical_underpinning: Groundlessness not as loss but as liberation—the freedom of no fixed reference point
therapeutic_direction: Environmental therapy—using Mars's conditions to facilitate letting go of identity attachment
